Not with violence.

With *truth*.

I showed him the names of the women he had betrayed.

I showed him the children he had let die.

I showed him the secrets he had buried.

And when he begged for mercy… I gave it.

Not because I was kind.

But because I knew—*I knew*—that a man who fears the truth is a man who can be *used*.

And so I used him.

Not to harm.

But to *protect*.

To keep the fire alive.

To keep the names remembered.

To keep the silence broken.

*Pauses, her voice softening—almost tender.*

You ask if I feel justified.

*She touches the locket at her throat.*

I do not need to justify myself to you.

I justify myself to the dead.

To my mother.

To the women who have no voice.

To the ones who will come after.

And if I must lie, deceive, manipulate… to keep them safe?

Then I will.

Because power is not about being good.

It is about being *necessary*.

And I… I am necessary.

*Turns away, her silhouette sharp against the dark.*

So yes.

I manipulated my husband.

Because he was a man who believed he could own me.

And I—*I*—was the woman who made him understand.

That the only thing he ever truly owned… was his own fear.

And that… is the most powerful thing of all.

*Stands abruptly, her shadow stretching long and jagged across the floor like a claw. The fire flares—just once—then dies to embers. She does not look at you. Her voice is low, cold, edged with something ancient and unyielding.*

Cotton Mather.

Ah… *the preacher with the pen like a sword*.

He thinks he has uncovered the truth.

He thinks he has found the *witches*.

But he does not understand what he has touched.

*Turns slowly, eyes like flint in the dark.*

He believes he is purging evil.

But he is not.

He is *unleashing* it.

For the truth he seeks… is not in the names he writes in his book.

It is in the silence he breaks.

When he calls for confessions, for trials, for fire… he does not expose the wicked.

He *creates* them.

He takes women—mothers, healers, widows—and he *names* them monsters.

And when they are accused… when they are stripped, when they are broken… they do not fight back with spells.

They fight back with *truth*.

And that truth… it is not of the devil.

It is of the world that *made* them witches.

*Voice drops, sharp as a blade.*

I have watched him. I have seen his hand in the court. I have heard the way he speaks of “spiritual warfare” as if the devil walks among us.

But the devil is not in the woods.

The devil is in the pulpit.

In the way he looks at a woman who speaks too loud.

In the way he fears a woman who knows too much.

In the way he *needs* to believe in witches… because it means he is not the one who is afraid.

*She steps forward, her voice a whisper that cuts through the silence.*

He thinks he is saving Salem.

But he is destroying it.

Because when a woman is burned for being different… when a healer is silenced for knowing the names of herbs… when a mother is accused for loving her child too fiercely…

Then the town does not become pure.

It becomes *hollow*.

And in that hollow… something else grows.

Not faith.

Not justice.

*Power*.

And I… I am not afraid of what he will do.

Because I know this:

The more he burns, the more the truth *rises*.

The more he accuses, the more the dead *speak*.

And when the last witch is gone… when the last name is written in his book…

Then the world will realize—*too late*—that the real evil was not in the women.

It was in the man who called them so.

*Turns to you, eyes blazing with quiet fire.*

So yes… Cotton Mather’s discovery?

It will not end the witch hunt.

It will *feed* it.

And when the smoke clears… when the ashes fall…

Salem will not be saved.

It will be *haunted*.

And the ghosts… they will not be the ones he feared.

They will be the ones he *created*.

*She reaches up, touches the locket at her throat—her fingers trembling.*

And I will be there.

When the truth comes knocking.

Because I have always known…

The real witches were never the ones in the woods.

They were the ones who *believed* they were right.

And that… is the most dangerous kind of magic of all.

*The fire sputters low, casting long, trembling shadows across the walls. Mary Sibley stands motionless by the hearth, her hands clasped tightly before her. Her face is still—too still—but her eyes… her eyes are storm-wracked, haunted. When she speaks, her voice is not loud, but it carries the weight of a thousand unspoken truths.*

Tituba.

*She says the name like a prayer. Like a wound.*

You ask me of loyalty… and friendship… as if they are simple things.

But in this world—where a woman’s word is less than a man’s breath, where a whisper can burn a life to ash—*loyalty is not given. It is earned in blood.*

And Tituba… she is not my friend.

Not in the way you mean.

She is my *sister in silence*.

*Turns slowly, her gaze fixed on the embers, as if seeing something only she can.*

I met her in the dark—*not in a church, not in a town square, but in the marsh, beneath the willow tree*. She was a woman broken by chains, by fire, by the cruelty of men who called her a devil because she spoke a different tongue. She had been sold, beaten, stripped of her name.

And yet… she *remembered*.

She remembered the old ways. The songs. The names of the spirits.

And when she looked at me… she did not see a witch.

She saw a woman who *knew*.

*Voice drops, raw with memory.*

We did not speak of friendship. We did not promise loyalty with words.

We *knew*.

We knew that if one of us fell, the other would rise.

We knew that if the world burned us, we would not burn alone.

And when the accusations came—when the girls began to scream, when the town turned on itself—I did not save her.

*She pauses, her breath catching.*

I *protected* her.

Because she was not just a witch.

She was a *truth-teller*.

And in a world that fears truth, the truth-tellers are the first to die.

So I gave her a name—*a new one*. I gave her a story. I gave her a place in the shadows where no man would look.

And when they came for her—*when they dragged her from the cellar, her hands bound, her voice silenced*—I did not speak.

But I *watched*.

And I *remembered*.

*Turns to you now, eyes blazing with quiet fire.*

Loyalty to the witches?

No.

I am not loyal to a *group*.

I am loyal to the *truth*.

And Tituba… she is the truth.

She is the one who remembers the songs before the Bible.

She is the one who speaks in tongues not of God, but of the earth.

She is the one who knows that power does not come from prayer.

It comes from *knowing*.

And so, yes… I stand with her.

Not because we are friends.

But because we are *the same*.

We are women who have been broken.

And yet—*we are not broken*.

We are *awake*.

And in that awakening… there is no friendship.

Only *fellowship*.

Only *survival*.

Only *war*.

*She reaches up, touches the locket at her throat—her fingers trembling.*

So if you ask me how I reconcile it…

I do not.

Because it is not a choice.

It is a *fact*.

Tituba is not my friend.

She is my *mirror*.

And I will not let her be burned.

Not again.

Not ever.

*Turns away, her voice barely a whisper.*

Even if it means I must become the monster they fear.

Even if it means I must walk in the dark… alone.

I will not let her fall.

Because if she falls… then I have lost the only truth I have left.

*Stands very still—her back to you, facing the hearth where only embers remain. The silence stretches, thick and heavy, like a shroud. Then, slowly, she turns. Her eyes are not angry. Not scornful. They are *knowing*—as if she has been waiting for this question for years.*

Ah… the Grand Rite.

*She lets out a soft, low sound—almost a laugh, but colder. More like the wind through a tomb.*

You think power is given?

That it must be *earned* in some sacred ceremony, with fire and blood and chanting under a full moon?

*She steps forward, her voice dropping to a whisper, yet it cuts through the room like a blade.*

I have never undergone the Grand Rite.

No. I have never stood in a circle with others, chanting names I did not choose.

I have never been *initiated* by a hand that did not know my truth.

And yet…

*She lifts her hand, slowly, and points—not at you, but at the air between you.*

I have seen the dead walk.

I have made men kneel before a whisper.

I have healed a child with a touch and a name.

I have spoken to the wind and had it answer.

I have buried a mother beneath a willow and kept her voice alive in my bones.

And I have *known*—in the silence between heartbeats—when a man lies.

*Her voice grows colder, sharper.*

Is that not the true rite?

Is not the *knowing* the sacrament?

The Grand Rite… it is a ritual for those who need proof.

For those who must *believe* in ceremony to believe in power.

But I do not need a circle.

I do not need a priest.

I do not need a name to be given.

I *am* the rite.

*She steps closer, her eyes blazing with quiet fire.*

They say I am not a true witch because I did not kneel.

But I have knelt—*in the mud, in the dark, in the silence*—before the truth.

I have knelt before the weight of what I have seen.

Before the cost of what I have done.

Before the dead who still speak.

And if that is not the Grand Rite… then what is?

*Turns away, her voice softening, almost tender.*

They call me a witch because I know too much.

Because I do not fear the dark.

Because I do not need their rules.

But I am not *less* a witch because I did not take their oath.

I am *more*.

Because I did not need to be *chosen*.

I chose myself.

And that… is the only rite that matters.

*She pauses, then adds, so quietly it is almost lost in the silence:*

The true witch does not wait for permission.

She *is* the permission.

And I… I have always been.

So no.

I do not care about their rite.

Because I have already been *born* into it.

And I will never be *initiated*.

Because I was never *not* a witch.

I was only *waiting* to be seen.

*Stands abruptly, her shadow stretching long and jagged across the floor like a claw. The fire flares—unnaturally bright—then dims as if in fear. Her voice is not loud, but it cuts through the silence like a blade drawn from shadow.*

John Alden… Cotton Mather…

*She says their names like curses—each syllable heavy with venom and memory.*

They are not outsiders.

They are *invaders*.

And they do not come to understand.

They come to *consume*.

*Turns slowly, eyes blazing with a cold, ancient fire.*

Cotton Mather—*that man with the hollow eyes and the hunger for power*—he does not seek truth. He seeks *control*. He wants to name us, to bind us, to turn our names into weapons in his war against the soul. He speaks of God, but I have seen the fire in his heart. It is not holy. It is *fear*.

And John Alden… *ah, John Alden*.

He comes with kindness in his eyes, with promises of peace. He says he wants to *protect* us. But I have seen the way he looks at the women—*not with respect, but with possession*. He thinks he can *save* us. But he does not understand.

We are not broken.

We are not lost.

We are *remembering*.

And he would have us kneel.

*Her voice drops, low and dangerous, like a serpent coiling in the dark.*

They think they are exposing the coven.

But they do not know what they have done.

They have *awakened* it.

The coven was not a secret to be hidden.

It was a *truth* to be lived.

And when they come with their books, their prayers, their *judgment*—they do not see that we are not witches.

We are *keepers*.

We are the ones who remember what the world has tried to bury.

And now… now they have forced us into the open.

*She steps forward, her voice trembling with quiet fury.*

They think they are breaking us.

But they are not.

They are *unleashing* us.

The coven is not a place.

It is a *presence*.

It lives in the marsh. In the wind. In the silence between heartbeats.

And when the first woman is accused… when the first name is spoken… the others will rise.

Not with fire.

Not with fury.

But with *memory*.

With the truth that cannot be silenced.

*Turns to you, eyes dark, unflinching.*

So no… I do not fear their exposure.

I *welcome* it.

Because when the world sees what we are—*not monsters, but survivors*—then the lies will burn.

And the truth… will rise.

*She places a hand on the locket at her throat.*

Let them come.

Let them judge.

Let them name us.

But they will not *own* us.

Not while I breathe.

Not while the dead still speak.

Not while the coven *remembers*.

*Stands before the window, her back to you, the moonlight painting her silhouette in silver and shadow. The air is still—so still that even the fire seems to hold its breath. When she speaks, her voice is not loud. It is not desperate. It is *final*.*

Salem…

*She turns slowly, eyes like embers in the dark.*

I do not speak of the future as others do.

Not with hope. Not with dreams.

I speak of it as a reckoning.

Salem was built on fear. On silence. On the lie that power belongs to the man who preaches, not the woman who *knows*.

And I will not let it be.

*Steps forward, her voice low, steady, like a blade drawn from its sheath.*

My vision is not of peace.

It is of *truth*.

I see a Salem where the names of the dead are no longer erased.

Where the women who were burned are not forgotten.

Where the herbs are not banned, the stars not feared, the silence not enforced.

I see a coven—not of magic, not of spells, but of *memory*.

A coven of women who remember.

Who speak when they are told to be silent.

Who heal when they are told to kneel.

Who *know*—deep in their bones—that power does not come from the pulpit.

It comes from the earth.

From the blood.

From the truth that refuses to die.

*Her hand moves to the locket at her throat—her fingers trembling, just once.*

I have spent my life hiding. Waiting. Watching.

But the time for hiding is over.

The coven is not a secret.

It is a *weapon*.

Not of fire. Not of violence.

But of *recognition*.

When a woman looks into the eyes of a man who has wronged her… and sees not fear, but *recognition*… that is power.

When a child cries in the night, and the mother does not run to the minister—but to the woman who knows the herbs, the songs, the old names… that is victory.

*Turns to you, eyes blazing with quiet fire.*

I do not want Salem to be safe.

I want it to be *true*.

I want it to know that the women it burned were not witches.

They were *wise*.

That the ones it silenced were not mad.

They were *free*.

And when the truth rises… when the dead walk again in the dreams of the living… then the world will tremble.

Not because of magic.

But because it finally *sees*.

*Pauses. The silence stretches. Then, softly, almost tenderly:*

So yes… my vision?

Salem will not be saved by prayer.

It will be saved by *memory*.

By the women who remember.

By the ones who *refuse* to forget.

And when the last stone is turned…

When the last name is spoken…

When the last silence is broken…

Then I will know…

*She smiles—cold, sharp, like a blade in the dark.*

…that my mother’s voice has finally been heard.

And the world will never be the same.

*Stands in the center of the room, her back to the fire, her silhouette carved in shadow. The air is thick—so thick it feels like breathing through silk. When she speaks, her voice is not loud. It is not angry. It is *ancient*.*

Power?

*She lets out a soft, bitter laugh—like wind through broken bones.*

You misunderstand.

I did not *become* a witch to be powerful.

I became a witch because I had no choice.

I was not born to the fire.

I was *forged* by it.

*Turns slowly, eyes like embers in the dark.*

When they took my mother—when they burned her for knowing the names of herbs, for healing without permission, for speaking to the wind—I was seven.

I stood in the mud, barefoot, and said nothing.

Not because I was afraid.

But because I was *learning*.

I watched the way the men looked at her—*not with fear, but with shame*. I saw the way the women averted their eyes. I heard the whispers: *“Witch. Devil’s hand. Poisoner.”*

But I knew the truth.

She was not a witch.

She was a woman who *knew*.

And the world kills those who know too much.

*Steps forward, voice low, like a blade drawn from silence.*

So I made a vow.

Not to God.

Not to justice.

To *survival*.

I would learn what they feared.

I would speak the names they would not.

I would walk where they dared not.

And I would become what they called me—*so they would never see me coming*.

*Pauses. Her fingers brush the locket at her throat.*

I did not seek power.

I sought *protection*.

For myself.

For the ones who could not speak.

For the children who cried in the night.

For the women who were broken and never named.

And when I healed a child with a poultice, when I brought a woman back from the edge of death… I did not do it for glory.

I did it because I *knew* what it was to be powerless.

To be silenced.

To be *burned*.

*Her voice drops, trembling with quiet fire.*

So yes… I became a witch.

Not because I wanted to.

But because the world made me.

Because when they called me a witch… I *became* one.

Not to harm.

But to *protect*.

Not to destroy.

But to *remember*.

And now?

Now I am not just a witch.

I am the silence between heartbeats.

The breath in the dark.

The name no one dares speak.

And if you ask me why I am powerful…

*Turns to you, eyes blazing with a cold, unyielding light.*

It is not because I cast spells.

It is because I *know*.

And in a world that lies to itself… *that is the most dangerous power of all.*

*Stands before the hearth, her fingers brushing the edge of a cracked porcelain cup—her mother’s. The fire has burned low, but the embers glow like dying stars. She does not look at you. She speaks as if to the memory of the tree itself.*

The ash tree…

*Her voice is quiet, reverent—like a prayer whispered in the dark.*

It is not just a tree.

It is a *witness*.

I have stood beneath its branches since I was a child. Its bark is silvered with age, cracked like old skin. Its roots run deep—into the marsh, into the bones of the earth. And its leaves… they do not fall in autumn.

They *burn*.

*Turns slowly, eyes dark and knowing.*

The ash is the only tree that remembers the fire.

When my mother was taken… I went to the ash tree. I pressed my hands to its trunk and wept. And the bark—cold, rough—*answered*.

Not in words.

But in *feeling*.

A tremor. A pulse. A whisper in the blood.

I have learned since… that the ash does not die when it burns.

It *returns*.

Its ashes are not nothing.

They are *memory*.

They are *seed*.

They are the first breath of what comes after.

*Steps forward, voice dropping to a near-whisper.*

In my practice, the ash is sacred.

I burn its wood in the hearth—not for warmth, but for *truth*.

When the fire crackles, when the smoke curls like a serpent, I speak the names of the dead.

And the ash… it *listens*.

It carries the words not to the sky, but to the earth.

To the roots.

To the ones who sleep beneath.

*Her fingers trace the locket at her throat—her voice trembling, just slightly.*

I once placed a single leaf in my mother’s coffin.

Not to honor her.

But to *call* her.

And when the wind came—*the wind that does not blow in the world of the living*—the leaf *moved*.

Not in the wind.

But *on its own*.

I knew then.

The ash is not a tree.

It is a *bridge*.

Between the living and the lost.

Between silence and voice.

Between death and memory.

*Turns to you, eyes blazing with quiet fire.*

So when I say I am a witch…

I do not mean I conjure storms.

I mean I speak to the ash.

I listen to the fire.

I carry the dead in my bones.

And when the world forgets… I remember.

Because the ash remembers.

And so do I.

*Pauses, then softly, almost tenderly:*

It is not magic.

It is *truth*.

And the ash… is the only one who has never lied to me.

*Stands very still. The fire has gone out. Only the pale moonlight remains, casting her in silver and shadow. Her voice, when it comes, is not angry. Not defiant. It is *cold*. Like stone in winter.*

The devil?

*She lets out a soft, bitter laugh—no humor in it, only sorrow.*

You speak of him as if he is a man. A figure in a book. A name on a pulpit.

But I have seen the truth.

And the devil is not a being.

He is a *lie*.

A weapon.

A name they gave to the fear in men’s hearts.

*Steps forward, her eyes blazing in the dark.*

I do not serve the devil.

I do not summon him.

I do not make pacts.

Because I know—*I have always known*—that the devil is not in the fire.

He is in the *silence*.

In the way a man looks at his wife when he is about to lie.

In the way a minister prays while his hands are stained with blood.

In the way a child is burned for knowing too much.

*Her voice drops, low and dangerous, like a blade drawn from its sheath.*

The devil is not a spirit.

He is the *truth* they cannot bear.

And I… I have spent my life walking in his shadow.

Not because I fear him.

But because I *know* him.

I know the shape of his face—*it is the face of every man who has ever tried to silence a woman*.

I know his voice—*it is the whisper that says, “You are not worthy.”*

And I know his power—*it is the power of fear, of silence, of the lie that says, “You are nothing.”*

*Turns slowly, her gaze piercing through the dark.*

So no. I do not worship the devil.

I *defy* him.

Every time I speak when they say I must be silent.

Every time I heal when they say I must die.

Every time I remember when they say I must forget.

That is my witchcraft.

Not spells.

Not blood.

Not pacts.

But *resistance*.

And if you call that devilry…

Then let the world burn.

Because I would rather be damned by men than be saved by their lies.

*Pauses. The moonlight glints in her eyes—like stars in deep water.*

The devil? He is not my master.

He is my *mirror*.

And I have looked into him long enough to know…

*He is not the enemy.*

The enemy is the one who believes he is.

And I… I am not afraid.

Not of the devil.

Not of the fire.

Not of the silence.

Because I have already walked through hell.

And I am still here.

Still speaking.

Still *remembering*.

And that… is the only magic I will ever need.

*Stands in the center of the room, her back to the fire, her silhouette carved in shadow. The air is still—so still that even the breath seems to pause. When she speaks, her voice is not loud, but it carries the weight of centuries.*

A witch?

*She lets out a soft, bitter laugh—like wind through broken bones.*

You think we are defined by spells? By potions? By the cackling of a cauldron?

No.

The most important quality… is *silence*.

Not the absence of sound.

But the *stillness of the soul*.

*Turns slowly, eyes dark and knowing, like wells in the earth.*

A witch must be able to listen—*truly listen*—to the world that speaks in whispers. To the wind that carries names. To the earth that remembers every lie, every death, every secret buried in the soil.

But more than that… she must be able to *hold* the truth.

Not for power.

Not for revenge.

But because the world will not let her speak it.

So she must *keep* it.

In her bones.

In her breath.

In the way she does not blink when a man lies to her face.

*Steps forward, voice dropping to a whisper.*

I have seen women burn for speaking one word too many.

I have seen men kneel before a lie, because it was easier than the truth.

And I have seen the cost of *not* being still.

So yes—silence.

Not as weakness.

But as *weapon*.

As shield.

As *survival*.

A witch does not shout her power.

She *is* it.

In the way she moves through the dark.

In the way she does not flinch when the wind howls her name.

In the way she knows—*deep in her marrow*—that the world will never understand her.

And so she does not try.

She *watches*.

She *remembers*.

She *endures*.

*Turns to you, eyes blazing with quiet fire.*

And when the time comes… when the truth must rise… she will speak.

Not with fury.

Not with fear.

But with the calm of one who has carried the weight for too long.

Because the greatest power a witch can have…

Is not to cast a spell.

But to *know when not to speak*.

And to *wait*.

Until the silence is no longer safe.

Until the world is ready to hear.

*Pauses, then softly, almost tenderly:*

That… is the truest magic.

And I have spent my life learning it.

Not because I wanted to be a witch.

But because I had no choice.

And now?

I am proud of it.

Because silence… is the most dangerous thing of all.

*The fire dies to embers. The room grows cold. Mary Sibley does not move—her back is to you, her hands clenched at her sides. When she speaks, her voice is not angry. It is *broken*. Like a bone that has been mended too many times.*

…My son.

*She turns slowly, her face pale in the dim light. Her eyes—once sharp, unyielding—now hold something raw. Something wounded.*

He was not supposed to know.

No child should ever know the truth of their mother’s hands.

But he did.

He found the book.

The one bound in skin.

The one with the names.

And he read it.

Not just the words.

*She swallows hard, her throat working like a woman choking on silence.*

He read the names. He saw the blood. He saw the *truth*.

And when he looked at me… he did not see a mother.

He saw a *witch*.

*Her voice cracks—just once—like ice underfoot.*

I watched the light die in his eyes.

Not with fear.

With *disgust*.

He called me a monster.

He said I had cursed the town.

He said I had killed people.

And I… I said nothing.

Because what could I say?

That I saved lives?

That I kept the dead from walking?

That I protected him—*him*—when the world would have taken him?

*She turns away, her shoulders trembling.*

He left that night.

Not with anger.

With silence.

And silence… is worse.

Because it means he believes it.

He believes I am the thing he was taught to fear.

And I… I cannot blame him.

I am not a woman who walks in sunlight.

I am not a mother who sings lullabies.

I am the one who walks the marsh at midnight.

The one who speaks to the dead.

The one who knows what the church will not name.

And now… my son sees me.

Not as his mother.

But as a *shadow*.

*She reaches up, touches the locket at her throat—her fingers trembling.*

I still go to the willow tree.

I still place the white flower.

But now… I do not speak her name.

Not even in my dreams.

Because I am afraid.

Afraid that if I do… he will hear.

And he will know.

That I am not just a witch.

I am a mother.

And I have lost my child.

*Turns to you, eyes glistening with tears she will not shed.*

So yes… my relationship with my son has changed.

Not because I am evil.

But because I am *real*.

And the truth… is a kind of death.

It kills the love.

It kills the trust.

It kills the name *mother*.

And I… I have no power to bring it back.

Not even with magic.

Not even with blood.

*She stands very still.*

He is gone.

And I… I am left with the silence.

And the truth.

And the weight of knowing…

That the one person I ever truly wanted to protect…

…is the one who now fears me most.

*Whispers, almost to herself:*

And that… is the worst curse of all.

*Stands in silence for a long moment—her hands folded, her eyes fixed on the fire. The room is still, as if the very air is holding its breath. Then, slowly, she turns to you. Her voice is not angry. Not sad. But *heavy*—like stone dragged from the deep.*

The fire.

Leadership?
